Notes: On 24 may 2022, the last four jurisdictions â Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon â previously requiring masks in elementary and secondary schools end their mandates â âall provinces in Canada have removed mask mandates in schoolsâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of NS, Yukon and PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103208/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/mask-mandates-end-in-all-atlantic-canadian-schools-but-health-officials-still-recommend-their-use-1.5916436  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103515/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20220519001  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522164219/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171554/https://yukon.ca/en/health-and-wellness/covid-19-information/k-12-school-guidelines-2021-22-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 30 may 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âprocedure for vaccine requirementâ remains in force until 1 June. âMemorial continues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âcontinues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. See Globe and Mail newspaper and MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-to-lift-its-covid-19-mask-mandate-for-provinces-public/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530170157/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/

On 1 june 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. At Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âMemorial suspended the requirement for masks on all campuses on June 1â¦ Memorial's procedure for vaccine requirement suspended on June 1 at 12:01 a.m. in alignment with the suspension of the NL Public Sector Policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools at any level and 0 now fits for unvaccinated students, who can now enter the post-secondary MUN campus âin alignment with the suspension of the [government of NL] Public Sector Policyâ. See Globe and Mail newspaper and MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-to-lift-its-covid-19-mask-mandate-for-provinces-public/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220602133007/www.mun.ca/covid19/

27 june 2022 is the start of the last week of the regular elementary and secondary school year in most Canadian jurisdictions, the national news service sums up âa topsy-turvy school year warped by the COVID-19 crisis. Many Canadian students cautiously returned to class this fall [of 2021] under strict pandemic protocols, such as mandatory masking and social distancing. As younger kids became eligible for vaccination late last year, it seemed like schools were settling into new routines. That was soon upended by the rampant spread of the Omicron variant, which saw some provinces extend winter breaks or switch to remote learning. Following the winter surge, public health measures were eased, allowing students to ditch their masks and gather together for school events.â Some post-secondary institutions are still requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated by governments. See Toronto Star newspaper and University Affairs Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626203022/https://www.universityaffairs.ca/news/news-article/covid-19-updates-for-canadas-universities/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626203205/https://www.thestar.com/life/2022/06/26/from-closures-to-near-normal-routines-students-look-back-on-covid-warped-school-year.html

On 30 may 2022 the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to recommend: âStaying home and keeping away from others if you test positive or are experiencing any symptoms, even if mildâ. The  âany symptoms, even if mildâ component of this recommendation is broader and more prescriptive than previous advice at the end of 2021: âstay at home when you're sick â¦ Be prepared to stay at home if you have symptomsâ. Some sub-national jurisdictions are not following the national governmentâs recommendation and have ended isolation rules for covid-positive patients. However, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canadaâs recommendation is available to all Canadians. See government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529132225/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html

The government of Canada announced that âon June 20, 2022, the vaccination requirement to board a plane or a train in Canada will be suspendedâ¦ Due to the unique nature of cruise ship travel, vaccination requirements for passengers and crew of cruise ships will continue to remain in effect.â There are some commercial domestic cruises solely within Canada. Unvaccinated persons who wish to travel â e.g., from Quebec City to Montreal or a destination in Ontario â can now do so by air or rail, even if their first preference to travel by commercial boat cruise remains unavailable. For most consumers, the principal appeals of a commercial boat cruise â dining, accommodation and sightseeing â outweigh traveling from one city to another. The removal of the vaccine mandate for domestic air and rail passengers means that travel within Canada is open to both vaccinated and unvaccinated persons. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220618114425/https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2022/06/suspension-of-the-vaccine-mandates-for-domestic-travellers-transportation-workers-and-federal-employees.html

On 27 June 2022, the new government of Canada policy remains in place effectiveâJune 20, 2022, the vaccination requirement to board a plane or a train in Canada will be suspendedâ¦ Due to the unique nature of cruise ship travel, vaccination requirements for passengers and crew of cruise ships will continue to remain in effect.â There are some commercial domestic cruises solely within Canada. Unvaccinated persons who wish to travel â e.g., from Quebec City to Montreal or a destination in Ontario â can now do so by air or rail, even if their first preference to travel by commercial boat cruise remains unavailable. For most consumers, the principal appeals of a commercial boat cruise â dining, accommodation and sightseeing â outweigh traveling from one city to another. The removal of the vaccine mandate for domestic air and rail passengers means that travel within Canada is open to both vaccinated and unvaccinated persons. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220618114425/https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2022/06/suspension-of-the-vaccine-mandates-for-domestic-travellers-transportation-workers-and-federal-employees.html

On 30 may 2022, Canada remains open to entry by non-citizens, but only those who meet the following requirements: âyou must qualify as a fully vaccinated traveller to enter Canada, unless you have a job in 1 of the following categories: Agricultural or food processing worker; Marine crew member; Make medical deliveries; Work with medical equipment or devicesâ. In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors subject to screening requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220530083940/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/visitors-workers-students

In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors subject to screening requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220606173237/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/visitors-workers-students

On 30 may 2022, the government of Canada continues with a ânational public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual risk management. While some sub-national government approaches are no longer consistent with the national governmentâs information campaign, 2G still warranted due to the national scope of Government of Canada public outreach efforts. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529160035/www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

On 30 may 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. In Canadaâs most populous province of Ontario: âDue to testing limitations, officials say the actual number of daily new cases is likely far higher than the figure reported.â See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529161107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529160646/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-covid-update-saturday-may-28-2022-1.6469644

On 6 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: ârapid antigen tests have replaced wide-scale PCR tests; fewer people are now eligible for PCR testing across the country after high demand for testing during the Omicron wave overwhelmed testing centresâ¦an infectious disease physician at the University of Alberta Hospital in Edmonton, saidâ¦ "the public does not have a way of being able to confirm they actually have COVID â¦â she noted that rapid tests have become less reliable when it comes to Omicronâ. See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605105043/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220603140724/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/rapid-test-cease-2022-phac-1.6475870

On 13 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: âthe rise of the highly transmissible Omicron variantâ¦ prompted governments to shift reliance from government-backed PCR testing to the mass distribution of rapid antigen tests Â­â the results of which are less accurate and are largely not collected by health authoritiesâ. On 20 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the Omicron caseload wave frustrated efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: âThe swarm of infections prompted many health authorities to stop relying on government-backed PCR testing and begin to mass-distribute rapid antigen. Results from those at-home tests are both less accurate than PCR tests and difficult, if not impossible, for health authorities to collect.â See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220617235453/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220617235210/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-health-canada-to-drop-covid-alert-contract-tracing-app-immediately-as/

On 27 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the Omicron caseload wave frustrated efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., the scientific director of the Ontario COVID-19 Science Advisory Table recommends: âThe logical way forward is careful surveillance using wastewater testing â¦ Canada currently has among the lowest G10 [refers to the group of 10 countries in the General Arrangements to Borrow to provide the International Monetary Fund (IMF) with additional funds] rates of PCR testingâ. See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627124910/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627124641/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-we-need-new-strategies-to-tackle-covid-this-fall/

On 30 may 2022, government of Canada advises that when individuals âtest positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in most jurisdictions to deal with high case numbers. In most cases, contact tracing responsibility is up to individuals who are symptomatic and/or have tested positive. For example, in Canadaâs most populous province of Ontario: âIf you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have tested positive, tell your close contacts that they have been exposedâ¦ Informing your contact will help stop the spread of the virus. Give them the link to this webpage, ontario.ca/exposed, so they can protect themselves and their contacts.â See Governments of Canada and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529161107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529161428/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/exposed

On 30 may 2022, in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): âTemporary restrictions to visitation/attendance are in place at all provincially operated acute care facilities, treatment facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homesâ¦ Each patient/resident can have up to two visitors at a timeâ. The vaccine mandate continues for staff including âVolunteers and hairdressersâ, but does not apply to visitors. Some NL facilities have limited visitors to 1, which still fits the definition of â2 = narrow restrictionsâ. Other provinces and territories have â1 = recommended guidanceâ rules for visitors regardless of vaccination status â e.g., New Brunswick (NB). In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530145808/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530144740/https://www.westernhealth.nl.ca/current-visitor-restrictions/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530150631/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530181759/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and PEI websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620181739/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-pei/visitor-policy-and-protocols-for-health-pei-facilities-including-long-term  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620182458/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620182900/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC, NB and PEI websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626195028/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-pei/visitor-policy-and-protocols-for-health-pei-facilities-including-long-term  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626195333/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220626195716/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/dam/gnb/Departments/h-s/pdf/Measures_RestrictionsNH_ARF.pdf

Effective 20 june 2022, the Canadian governmentâs âPolicy on COVID-19 Vaccination for the Core Public Administration (CPA) Including the Royal Canadian Mounted Police will be suspendedâ¦they will no longer be required to be vaccinated as a condition of employment. As such, employees who are on administrative leave without pay for noncompliance with the Policy in force until now will be contacted by their managers to arrange their return to regular work duties.  Crown corporations and separate agencies will also be asked to suspend vaccine requirements, and the vaccination requirement for supplier personnel accessing federal government workplaces will also be suspended. With the suspension of vaccination requirements, employees placed on unpaid leave may return to work. ...In addition, federally regulated transport sector employers will no longer be required to have mandatory vaccination policies in place for employees. Due to the unique nature of cruise ship travel, vaccination requirements for passengers and crew of cruise ships will continue to remain in effect.â For the military: âThe [Canadian Armed Forces] CAF is currently assessing the need for â¦ the [Chief of Defence Staff] CDS Directives on COVID-19 Vaccinationâ¦ the CDS Directives remain in effect until further noticeâ. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220618114425/https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2022/06/suspension-of-the-vaccine-mandates-for-domestic-travellers-transportation-workers-and-federal-employees.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220619171339/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence/maple-leaf/defence/2022/06/message-suspension-mandatory-vaccination-federal-government-employees.html

On June 12, 2022, the US changed its requirement for negative tests.     "As of 12:01AM ET on June 12, 2022, CDC will no longer require air passengers traveling from a foreign country to the United States to show a negative COVID-19 viral test or documentation of recovery from COVID-19 before they board their flight. For more information, see Rescission: Requirement for Negative Pre-Departure COVID-19 Test Result or Documentation of Recovery from COVID-19 for all Airline or Other Aircraft Passengers Arriving into the United States from Any Foreign Country."    However, this does not result in a change in stringency level as (1) international passengers are still required to be vaccinated and (2) vaccination check is considered a form of screening.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220612074246/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel/index.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220613044024/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/proof-of-vaccination.html

Per the USA government guidance on employment benefits, "The federal government allowed states to change their laws to provide COVID-19 unemployment benefits for people whose jobs have been affected by the coronavirus pandemic."    See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605014140/https://www.usa.gov/unemployment
Debt and contract relief is not being provided at the federal level.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220611182127/https://www.usa.gov/help-with-bills
The CDC still maintains a robust public information campaign.     See archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612161104/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html
